vectorData.altText: 11. This structure (A) invaginates into the underlying tissue. What is it called?

epidermal ridges

dermal papillae

Dermal ridges, only present in thick skin, are more gross folds of the dermal-epidermal interface that create “friction ridges” on hands and feet; this is the basis of dermatoglyphs or fingerprints
­ surface area (SA) between epidermis & dermis; more pronounced in body regions that experience greater mechanical stress

The greater the surface area of the dermal-epidermal interface, the greater the:
number of hemidesmosomes, and therefore adhesion between the epidermis and the underlying basement membrane, keeping our epidermis more tightly bound down in regions exposed to more friction
gas, nutrient and metabolite exchange between the avascular epidermis and the richly vascularized dermis; 
population of dividing cells in the germinal layer, and therefore the number of keratinocytes being produced and entering more superficial layers
All of these factors are particularly important in thick skin, which has the greatest dermal-epidermal SA.

That's right! Epidermal ridges together with the dermal papillae increase SA btw epidermis and dermis for a) enhanced adhesion of layers, b) increased molecular exchange and c) greater number of keratinocytes.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
